title: Lennox Gastaut Syndrome LGS
author: Authored By
description: What is Lennox-Gastaut syndrome? The Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (LGS) is a type of epilepsy with multiple different types of seizures, particularly tonic (stiffening) and atonic (drop) seizures. Intellectual development is usually delayed and often worsens over time.
cleaned_text: you by LGS Together What is Lennox-Gastaut syndrome? - The Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (LGS) is a multiple different [types of seizures](/learn/types-epilepsy-syndromes), particularly [tonic](/learn/types-seizures/tonic-seizures)(stiffening) and [atonic](/learn/types-seizures/atonic-seizures)(drop) seizures. - Intellectual development is usually delayed and often worsens over time. Behavioral problems, including hyperactivity, agitation, aggression and autism, are common. - Lennox-Gastaut syndrome is a type of "epileptic encephalopathy." This terms means that the frequent seizures and very abnormal [EEG (electroencephalograph)](/learn/diagnosis/eeg)activity worsens cognitive and behavioral problems. - The cause of the disorder is unknown in 1 out of 4 children. Learn More: [Contact Our Helpline](/helpline) How common is it? "Lennox-Gastaut syndrome accounts for only 2 to 5% of childhood epilepsies." Yet children with this type of epilepsy are well-known to both pediatric and adult neurologists. Seizures in people with LGS are hard to control and continue throughout life. The intellectual and behavioral problems seen with LGS add to difficulties in managing life. Although seizures often begin by early preschool years, it typically takes time for all the clinical and EEG features to appear. - Diagnosis may not be obvious when seizures begin. It may take several years to diagnosis LGS. - Some young children have the types of seizures typical for LGS but don't have all features of LGS. These children need close follow-up to watch for other signs of LGS. - LGS beginning after age 10 is not common. In many cases, Lennox-Gastaut syndrome develops after another type of epilepsy, such as [West syndrome](/learn/types-epilepsy-syndromes/infantile-spasms-west-syndrome) (infantile spasms), [Ohtahara syndrome](/learn/types-epilepsy-syndromes/ohtahara-syndrome) or [Epilepsy in Infancy with Migrating Focal Seizures](/learn/types-epilepsy-syndromes/epilepsy-infancy-migrating-focal-seizures). Most children have developmental or intellectual problems before LGS is diagnosed. LGS is slightly more common in boys. No racial differences have been documented. How Is It Diagnosed? For a child or adult to be diagnosed with Lennox-Gastaut syndrom, three key features must be present. These include the following. Multiple Seizure Types - Seizure types in LGS include [tonic](/learn/types-seizures/tonic-seizures), [atonic or drop attacks](/learn/types-seizures/atonic-seizures), [atypical absence](/learn/types-seizures/atypical-absence-seizures), [myoclonic](/learn/types-seizures/myoclonic-seizures), and generalized [tonic-clonic](/learn/types-seizures/tonic-clonic-seizures)seizures starting in childhood. - Seizures begin in childhood but different types may emerge over time. [Focal](/learn/types-seizures)(one area of the brain) seizures become more common in teens and adults. A Characteristic EEG Pattern The EEG during wakefulness shows diffuse or widespread background slowing and slow spike-wave bursts. In sleep, a characteristic pattern, termed "generalized paroxysmal fast activity" is seen. This may sometimes correlate with subtle tonic activity. Cognitive Impairment, Behavior Problems or Developmental Delay Prior to seizure onset, 70-80% (or 7 to 8 out of 10) of children have a history of delayed development and neurological problems. When seizures begin, these problems are almost always seen and often get worse over time. What causes LGS? There are many possible causes of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome. The cause is eventually found in over 75% (3 out of 4) of people. "There are 3 main groups of known causes." Structural Causes [Structural causes](/learn/epilepsy-due-specific-causes) are divided into two main groups: - Congenital Brain Malformations: This term means that part of the brain has developed abnormally, making it more prone to seizures. - The abnormal brain development may be caused by a [genetic abnormality](/learn/epilepsy-due-specific-causes/genetic-causes-epilepsy/genetics-basics), an [infection](/learn/epilepsy-due-specific-causes)that occurred early during pregnancy, or some type of injury that occurred early in pregnancy. - Often the cause of the abnormal brain development is not known. - When a child is diagnosed with a congenital brain malformation, it is normal for mothers to worry that this may be due to something they did during the pregnancy, such as having a glass of wine, being briefly exposed to a certain chemical, or spending a brief period of time in a Jacuzzi. They should be reassured that these activities do not lead to severe congenital brain malformations. - The abnormal brain development may be caused by a - Acquired Brain Injury: This means that the brain has developed normally, but a brain injury occurs later. Brain injuries can include lack of adequate oxygen or blood flow, stroke, bleeding, infections such as meningitis or encephalitis, or head injury. Brain malformations or injuries may affect focal (specific) areas of the brain or may affect the brain more diffusely. Genetic Disorders [Genetic disorders](/learn/epilepsy-due-specific-causes/genetic-causes-epilepsy/epilepsy-and-genes) are increasingly recognized as a cause of early-onset, severe epilepsy such as LGS. - Sometimes, genetic disorders can lead to structural changes in the brain, such as in [Tuberous Sclerosis Complex](/learn/epilepsy-due-specific-causes/structural-causes-epilepsy/specific-structural-epilepsies). - In other genetic disorders, the brain appears normal on [MRI (magnetic resonance imaging)](/learn/diagnosis/looking-brain/mri). - The specific genetic disorder can result in other symptoms, such as characteristic facial appearance (seen in Down syndrome) or other neurological symptoms (like movement disorders or developmental problems). - Many genetic disorders that lead to an early onset epilepsy arise "de novo." This means that there is no family history of other affected relatives. Learn about Genetics to Better Understand One Cause of LGS Metabolic Disorders [Metabolic disorders](/learn/epilepsy-due-specific-causes) rarely cause LGS, but some may be associated with specific treatments. - It's important to exclude these during the diagnostic work-up with [blood](/learn/treating-seizures-and-epilepsy/seizure-and-epilepsy-medicines/blood-testing)and urine tests. - Many metabolic disorders can be associated with specific changes on brain MRI scans. How do you treat LGS? "The first treatment for anyone epilepsy is antiseizure medications." Antiseizure Medications The first treatment for any person with epilepsy, including children and adults with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, is [antiseizure medications](/learn/treating-seizures-and-epilepsy/seizure-and-epilepsy-medicines). Seizures with LGS usually are not controlled with one seizure medicine. Two or more medications are often needed. Even then, medicines may not control seizures enough and the person continues to be at risk for [injuries](/learn/challenges-epilepsy/injuries-and-illnesses), [seizure emergencies](/learn/challenges-epilepsy/seizure-emergencies), and worsening of [cognition](/learn/challenges-epilepsy/thinking-and-memory) (thinking) and [behavior](/learn/challenges-epilepsy/moods-and-behavior). - Most seizures in LGS don't respond well to usual seizure medicines, and [side effects](/learn/treating-seizures-and-epilepsy/seizure-and-epilepsy-medicines/side-effects)can be hard to tolerate. - Partial relief from seizures may be found with medications. - One of the most common seizure medicines used in LGS is [valproic acid](/medications/valproic-acid). - Medicines that have proven to reduce seizures in many persons with LGS are [fenfluramine](/article/2017/10/promising-results-announced-investigational-drug-treating-dravet-syndrome). However, other medications may also be helpful. - One of the most common seizure medicines used in LGS is - When seizures don't respond to medicines, it's time to look at other treatments. Dietary Therapies [Dietary treatments](/learn/treating-seizures-and-epilepsy/dietary-therapies) can often reduce the number of seizures in people with LGS. The number or doses of some seizure medications may be lowered if diet therapy works well. The dietary therapies used for LGS and other forms of epilepsy include the [ketogenic diet](/learn/treating-seizures-and-epilepsy/dietary-therapies/ketogenic-diet), [modified Atkins diet](/learn/treating-seizures-and-epilepsy/dietary-therapies/modified-atkins-diet), and [Low Glycemic Index diet](/learn/treating-seizures-and-epilepsy/dietary-therapies/low-glycemic-index-treatment). - These diets restrict some food choices, so they can be difficult to stay on for long periods. - The ketogenic diet is most restrictive and is often used when several medications have failed. It can also be easily given in children or people who get their food and nutrition through a tube in their stomach. Parents or other caregivers can control the types and amount of foods given. The ketogenic diet is prescribed by a physician and carefully monitored by a dietitian. - The modified Atkins diet and low glycemic diet are more liberal and easier to use. These are being tried more in adolescent and adults. [Learn more about dietary therapies](/learn/treating-seizures-and-epilepsy/dietary-therapies) so you can discuss this option with your health care provider. [Follow our Keto News](/connect/seizure-and-epilepsy-news/keto-news) to stay up to date about dietary therapies. Surgery and Devices Rarely, people with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome will be found to have a focal area of brain that can be removed to help control seizures. - Corpus Callosotomy - This [type of brain surgery](/learn/treating-seizures-and-epilepsy/surgery/types-epilepsy-surgery)can be done to separate some of the connections between the two sides of the brain. - This surgery has been very helpful to decrease the frequency of [drop attacks](/learn/types-seizures/atonic-seizures). Since these are the most frequent seizures in LGS and cause the most injury, corpus callostomy is often considered for people with LGS. - This - Vagus Nerve Stimulation (VNS) - The most common [device](/learn/treating-seizures-and-epilepsy/neuromodulation-devices)used in people with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome is [vagus nerve stimulation](/learn/treating-seizures-and-epilepsy/devices/vagus-nerve-stimulation-vns)with VNS Therapy®. - Surgery is needed to [place the device](/learn/treating-seizures-and-epilepsy/devices/vagus-nerve-stimulation/placement-programming-and-safety-vagus-nerve-stimulation-vns)in the left chest area and the left side of the neck. It does not require surgery in the brain. - Repeat surgeries may be needed after a number of years to replace the generator when the battery in it wears down or to replace an electrode wire. This type of surgery is an outpatient procedure that usually takes 1 to 2 hours at most. [Learn more about VNS](/learn/treating-seizures-and-epilepsy/devices/vagus-nerve-stimulation-vns)so you can discuss this option with your health care team. - The most common Rescue Medications About 50 to 75% of people with LGS have one or more episodes of [non-convulsive status epilepticus](/learn/challenges-epilepsy/seizure-emergencies/status-epilepticus). - This type of [seizure emergency](/learn/challenges-epilepsy/seizure-emergencies)consists of ongoing [atypical absence seizures](/learn/types-seizures/atypical-absence-seizures). - The person's awareness is altered and they may appear confused for long periods. - They may have frequent to near continuous twitching of the arms or face ( [myoclonic seizures](/learn/types-seizures/myoclonic-seizures)). [Atonic](/learn/types-seizures/atonic-seizures)symptoms, such as a drop of the head or part of the body, may happen with clusters of brief [tonic](/learn/types-seizures/tonic-seizures)(stiffening) seizures too. [Convulsive status epilepticus](/learn/challenges-epilepsy/seizure-emergencies/status-epilepticus) can also occur in people with LGS. This type of seizure emergency happens when a [generalized seizure](/learn/types-seizures) with loss of conscioueness lasts 5 minutes or longer or [repeated seizures](/learn/challenges-epilepsy/seizure-emergencies) happen without the person coming back to awareness between seizures. "Status epilepticus is a seizure emergency." - It is critical that families and caregivers of children and adults with LGS become familiar with the [types of seizures](#Seizure-Types)their loved one has. Families should know [seizure first aid](/living-epilepsy/seizure-first-aid-and-safety/first-aid-seizures-stay-safe-side)and have a [plan for responding to seizures](/learn/managing-your-epilepsy/seizure-action-plans). [Rescue therapies](/living-epilepsy/seizure-first-aid-and-safety/responding-seizures/using-rescue-medications), or treatments that can be given to help stop or shorten clusters of seizures, are an important part of seizure care for people with LGS. Family Support Families of people with LGS should work closely with a social worker to [find resources](/connect/247-helpline) to maximize quality of life for their child. Respite help is also important for the family. As the child grows older and ages out of school resources, other help will be needed. The social worker can help explore [financial resources](/living-epilepsy/independent-living/financial-planning/financial-planning-child), such as social security and health insurance options, vocational or day programs, and residential or assisted living options, if appropriate. Children with LGS also will need an Individualized Education Plan. Many may benefit from ongoing physical, occupational and speech therapy. It's important to involve the [school nurse](/living-epilepsy/our-training-and-education/seizure-training-school-nurses-caring-students) and mental health resources early. "We Can Help You Find Resources and Support" - Call our 24/7 Helpline "Search for Resources" - Reach out to your [local Epilepsy Foundation](/affiliates) Be Prepared When A Seizure Happens - Know - and teach others - [seizure first aid](/living-epilepsy/seizure-first-aid-and-safety/first-aid-seizures-stay-safe-side). It's Stay. Safe. Side. - Fill out - and share - a [seizure action plan](/learn/managing-your-epilepsy/seizure-action-plans)so others will know what you want them to do for you. Learn More: [Find Your Local Epilepsy Foundation](/local) What is the long term outcome? The long-term prognosis for seizures, learning and behavior is worrisome. Seizures with LGS unfortunately do not respond well to seizure medications. Behavior problems can be very challenging in many people. Psychosocial needs of people with LGS and their families are critical to address early and on an ongoing basis, because the needs of the person with epilepsy and their family change over time. - Establish an [epilepsy team](/learn/managing-your-epilepsy/managing-my-seizures-101/my-health-care-team)early that includes epilepsy doctors, nurses, social workers, mental health providers, and rehabilitation specialists. An [epilepsy center](/learn/drug-resistant-epilepsy/comprehensive-epilepsy-center)has a team of health care professionals who specialize in the diagnosis, care, and treatment of people with [difficult to control seizures](/treatment/medicines/drug-resistant-epilepsy). [Find an epilepsy center](/connect/find-epilepsy-specialist/find-epilepsy-center)near you. - Getting support from other families living with LGS can be invaluable. Reach out to family organizations like the [LGS Foundation](https://www.lgsfoundation.org/)for support, connection, resources and services. Summary Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome continues to present great challenges to children and adults with the syndrome, their families, and their caregivers. Much more [research is needed](/about-us/research-and-new-therapies) to identify better therapies of all types. New advances in [seizure detection](/release/2018/10/epilepsy-foundation-awards-3-million-grant-international-team-scientists-improve), recording, and [alerting](/learn/early-death-and-sudep/sudep/role-seizure-alerts), as well as other safety and protection devices, are avenues that need further attention by families, health care providers, and researchers. These types of treatments and services can improve safety management and quality of life for people with LGS and their caregivers. - Find out [what happens in a clinical trial](/clinical-trials-portal-overview)and why it's important to participate [Find a clinical trial](/clinical_trials) - Learn about [our efforts to advance innovation](/about-us/research-and-new-therapies/innovation)to help families in a time frame that matters.
